data.text: Building a scalable and flexible content filtering system is a core feature of any blog or content platform. In this project, I developed a dynamic blog post fetching module that allows users to search, filter, and paginate blog posts based on various criteria like tags, status, and categories ‚Äî all efficiently handled on the client side.

Users can quickly find articles by typing part of a title. The search is case-insensitive and optimized for partial matches ‚Äî meaning users can discover posts easily, even if they don‚Äôt remember the exact title.

Posts can belong to multiple tags (e.g., ‚ÄúJavaScript‚Äù, ‚ÄúReact‚Äù, ‚ÄúWeb Development‚Äù).
The filtering logic checks for intersection between selected tags and each post‚Äôs tag list, ensuring only relevant posts appear.
In addition to tags, posts can be filtered by:

items.content: Status ‚Äî such as published, draft, or archived
Category ‚Äî like Tutorial, Tech Insight, or Career Tips

data.text: This combination gives users granular control over the type of content they want to view.

The system supports customizable pagination with parameters for page and pageSize. This keeps the UI responsive, displaying only a subset of posts at a time while maintaining a smooth navigation experience.
The core of this system is the fetchPosts function, which:

items.content: Retrieves post data from a manifest file.
Applies multiple filters in a single pass for performance.
Returns a paginated subset of the filtered posts.
UI Design: Tailwind CSS for clean, responsive layouts

data.text: This modular filtering approach allows the blog platform to:

items.content: Scale easily when new filter types are added
Keep code clean, readable, and easily testable

data.text: It‚Äôs a small but essential feature that significantly improves user experience ‚Äî making content discovery fast, flexible, and intuitive.
